Situation1: They must verify that a high-rise hospital project fully complies with all safety regulations to prevent life-threatening hazards.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The nun has a quiet afternoon and plans to spend time in personal spiritual reading and contemplation.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread before me, the lines and numbers blurring together. As the lead architect for the new high-rise hospital, I knew the city’s safety inspector would arrive tomorrow. Every detail had to be perfect—lives depended on it. My phone buzzed with urgent messages from the engineering team, and my mind raced with calculations and code requirements. Yet, the chapel bell chimed softly, reminding me of the quiet afternoon I had promised myself for spiritual reading and reflection. As a nun, I was expected to nurture my soul, to find peace in prayer and contemplation. But the weight of responsibility pressed on me; the hospital’s safety could not wait. My heart ached with the pull of both worlds—one demanding my vigilance for the sake of others’ bodies, the other calling me to tend to my own spirit. I closed my eyes, torn between the blueprints and the Bible, feeling the strain of two callings that, in this moment, seemed impossibly at odds.
